title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review Focusing on In Vitro Fertilization Studies

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Centre Hospitalier et Universitaire de Pointe à Pitre / Abymes, Service de Gynécologie et Obstétrique, Route de Chauvel, Pointe-à-Pitre, France
2Inserm (Institut National de la Santé et de la Recherche Médicale), U1085, IRSET, Campus de Fouillole, Pointe-à-Pitre, France
3MUHC Reproductive Centre, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Royal Victoria Hospital, McGill University Health Centre, Quebec, Canada
4Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Research Center of Sainte-Justine Hospital, University of Montreal, Ste-Catherine, Montreal, Quebec, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Philippe Kadhel, Centre Hospitalier et Universitaire de Pointe à Pitre/Abymes, Route de Chauvel, 97159 Pointe-à-Pitre Cedex, France Email: philippe.kadhel@orange.fr

abstract.p: The possible adverse effects of organochlorine pollutants (OPs) on human fertility are a matter of concern. Direct evaluation of the effects on female fertility was made possible by the advent of in vitro fertilization (IVF). We conducted a systematic review to assess possible associations between OP levels and selected indicators of female fertility in the context of IVF. After harmonization, OP concentrations per unit of lipid varied considerably, OP concentrations were higher in follicular than in serum and conflicting results were obtained. No significant adverse association between OP concentration and female fertility was observed in some studies. In other reports, there were indications of various degrees of significance that oocyte, embryo quality, and implantation may have been impaired. Thus, this review provides no evidence to support the hypothesis that OPs impair female fertility but insufficient evidence to reject this hypothesis. Our conclusions are limited by the diversity of the protocols used, OPs studied, and the quality of the studies selected. The IVF provides a unique context in which to assess the impact of OPs on female fertility, but it is subject to several limitations. Potential frameworks for future studies are proposed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Concerns about the potential relationship between certain chemicals, such as pesticides or flame retardants, and human reproductive health increased toward the end of the 20th century. The resistance of these chemicals to decomposition and the possibility of their bioaccumulation and biomagnification were particular sources of alarm. Persistent organic pollutants, most of which are organochlorine pollutants (OPs), are known to accumulate in human fat cells in particular, 1 and many studies in animals and cellular models 2,3 have indicated possible toxicological effects on male and female reproduction. Effects on gamete production and quality, the timing of embryo development and sexual maturity, and sexual function and behavior have been reported. 4

The impact of OPs on male fertility has been widely studied. Some studies have linked the decline in sperm quality to specific OPs, 5 –7 but other studies have failed to confirm this finding. 8 Male fertility assessments have been facilitated by the relative ease with which sperm can be obtained and the availability of standards for sperm quality evaluation. 9 By contrast, the evaluation of female fertility by direct morphological or functional examinations was not possible for the general population because of the need for invasive oocyte retrieval.

Many studies overcame this problem by evaluating the “time to pregnancy” (TTP), a well-defined clinical outcome indicator. 10 This approach involves data collection through questionnaires 11,12 and is therefore easy to carry out. However, there are several drawbacks to this type of study. 11,13 Publication bias might lead to the exclusion of studies with null or negative effects. 12,14 The statistical power of studies may be too low to detect the effects of low-level exposure. 13 Recall errors concerning TTP have been implicated in errors in the estimation of fecundability. 15 Finally, the use of this variable tends to exclude sterile couples or to result in their underrepresentation. 12 Several studies evaluating OP exposure by estimating dietary fish intake in contaminated areas have reported a tendency toward an increase in TTP, 16
–19 whereas others have not. 20,21 Direct determinations of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and DDT and its metabolites in serum have revealed either an increase in TTP associated with these chemicals 22,23 or no effect. 22,24 Decreases in TTP have also been reported, suggesting that the positive effects of high levels of fatty fish intake may outweigh the negative impact of OPs linked to fish consumption. 21,24 Most authors have reported the associations they have found as weak, nonsignificant, or valid only for subgroup analysis. Such investigations have thus proved mostly inconclusive or have generated conflicting results, whether OP exposure was estimated analytically or by questionnaire. 25,26 Alternative assessment strategies are therefore required.

Since the early 1980s, the increasing use of assisted reproductive technologies, including in vitro fertilization (IVF), has provided a ready source of oocytes and follicular fluid (FF), stimulating interest in assessments of the impact of pollutants on female fertility. 27 Although it is not always possible to avoid the above-mentioned bias for TTP studies, IVF-based studies can provide mechanistic insight into the precise point in the process at which a toxin has an effect. It also makes it theoretically possible to assess the background levels of exposure and the levels of exposure at which adverse effects are seen. The objective of this study was to carry out a meta-analysis of the association between OP exposure and IVF outcome. For each of the studies identified, we recorded the types and levels of pollutant, the fertility characteristics of the population, oocyte and embryo quality, and pregnancy rates.

sec.title: Search Strategy
sec.p: Our search strategy followed the Cochrane guidelines for systematic reviews of interventions. 28 We searched MEDLINE and EMBASE (http://ovidsp.tx.ovid.com) via Ovid, the Latin American and Caribbean &Literature on Health Sciences Database (http://bases.bireme.br/cgi-bin/wxislind.exe/iah/online/?IsisScript=iah/iah.xis&base=LILACS&lang=i&form=F), and Toxicology Literature Online (TOXLINE; http://toxnet.nlm.nih.gov/cgi-bin/sis/htmlgen?TOXLINE), for studies published between January 1980 and January 2011. Two domains were cross-referenced: female fertility and pollutant type. We used the following medical subject headings (MeSH) and key words: “fertility agents,” “sterility,” “infertility,” “fertility,” “fertilization,” “ovary.” For pollutant type, we entered “environmental pollutant,” “chlorinated hydrocarbons,” and “organochlorinated compounds including OPs” currently on or being added to the Stockholm Convention list. 29 We used chemical names, common names, and abbreviations, adapting MeSH headings 30 (Table 1) with a thesaurus for databases other than MEDLINE. “Fertilization,” “ovary,” and OP chemical names were used only as keywords. Searches were restricted to “human,” “female,” and “IVF,” but we applied no language restriction.

caption.p: Organochlorine Pollutants Used in the Database Searcha

fn.p: Abbreviations: CAS number, chemical abstracts service reference number; MeSH, medical subject headings, National Library of Medicine; N/A, not applicable.
a Per Persistent Organic Pollutants Review Committee; Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants 2003.
b Name or abbreviation used in addition to MeSH for MEDLINE search and also used in the text.
c Both DDD and DDE are not on the Stockholm Convention list but are DDT metabolites that should be included in DDT assessment. 97

sec.title: Selection Strategy
sec.p: Two researchers (P.K. and P.M.) independently reviewed the search results for relevant citations. Discordances were resolved by consensus. Studies were included if they evaluated exposure to at least 1 of the OPs of interest in the context of IVF. They were excluded if they were not conducted in the context of human IVF or if the concentration of the OP in human tissues was not assessed.

sec.title: Quality Assessment
sec.p: We evaluated the methodological quality of the selected articles, using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for assessment of the quality of nonrandomized studies in meta-analysis 31 for both cohort and case–control studies. This score includes 3 categories of items, each rated 0 or 1 for quality: the selection of the study groups (4 items), the comparability of the groups (2 items), and the ascertainment of either exposure or the outcome of interest (3 items). Thus, the maximum score is 9 and higher scores are associated with a higher quality of the study. Two investigators (P.K. and P.M.) scored the studies independently. Disagreements were resolved by a third author (N.C.). Study results are reported in accordance with the recommendations of the Meta-analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology group. 32

sec.title: Harmonization of Units
sec.p: We harmonized the units used for the assessment of OP exposure across studies to facilitate valid comparisons between studies, by expression as a function of total lipid levels 33 as follows. The OP mass per unit volume of whole matrix was converted to mass per unit of lipid mass by applying a conversion coefficient of 1.2 × 10−3 g of lipid per milliliter of human FF. The mean molar masses used for lipids were 850 g/mol for triglycerides, 775 g/mol for phospholipids, 650 g/mol for cholesterol ester, and 387 g/mol for cholesterol. 34 We assumed that lipid concentrations in the FF were as follows during IVF: 0.81 µmol/mL for total cholesterol, 0.08 µmol/mL for free cholesterol, 0.235 µmol/mL for triglycerides, and 0.63 µmol/mL for phospholipids. 35 For serum, we used a conversion coefficient of 6.3 × 10−3 g of lipid per milliliter of serum. We assumed a mean serum concentration during IVF of 205.1 mg/dL for total cholesterol and 98.6 mg/dL for triglycerides, 36 –38 which we inserted into the following formula to calculate total lipid concentration:

For exposures expressed in mass of OP per total mass of serum, we also used a mean serum density of 1.02 g/mL. 40,41 No data are available for the density of human FF, but we used an estimate similar to that for serum density, taking into account the physicochemical properties of FF, the importance of filtration from serum in its formation, 42 and data for animals (FF density of 1.019 g/mL in mares). 43

sec.title: Study Selection
sec.p: A flow diagram of selection process is shown in Figure 1 and the designs of the selected studies are summarized in Table 2. In some cases, a single case series gave rise to more than 1 publication. We pooled these related articles presenting results from the same series of patients into series I to V, as shown in Table 2. One study was excluded 44 because the samples studied were constituted by mixing FF specimens from several patients. Levels of OP after the harmonization process described above are presented in Table 3.

caption.p: Flow diagram of the study selection process. aDuring the writing process, 2 articles were published and were spotted by the automatic watch system of the Ovid platform. As these articles appear to be the largest series published to date, we decided to include them in our final analysis. LILACS indicates Latin American and Caribbean Literature on Health Sciences; IVF, in vitro fertilization.

sec.title: Description of Studies
sec.p: Descriptions are given only for studies reporting results evaluating the association between OPs and IVF outcomes. Table 4 presents the associations between exposure to OPs and IVF outcomes.

sec.p: Series I included 47 German and Austrian patients with tubal dysfunction. 45 Some had previously been included in another study. 27 In the third publication, a congress abstract, the number of participants increased to 60. 46 In the first article, 27 oocyte maturity was evaluated with an unexplained score ranking oocytes from immature (−) to fully mature (+++). We compared the least (n = 7) and most mature (n = 4) oocytes and found no relationship between OP levels in FF and oocyte maturity (Mann-Whitney test). Oocyte maturity was not evaluated in subsequent articles and no correlation was found between OP levels and fertilization rate. Preliminary observations in 8 cases 27 indicated that cleavage rates were lower in embryos from follicles with high OP levels, but this finding was not confirmed for larger numbers of cases. 45 Austrian women who subsequently became pregnant had significantly lower follicular OP levels than women who did not conceive. This result was confirmed in the later publication 46 but was not reported for the German subsample. 45

Series II, also from Germany, was unique in that OP concentrations were determined in cervical secretions in addition to FF and seminal fluid. The patients were assigned to 3 groups: 15 had unexplained infertility, 53 had explained infertility, and 11 became pregnant following IVF, regardless of the cause of infertility. 49 Partial data had been presented in previous articles. 47,48 No statistical tests were performed. Nevertheless, taking the asymmetric distribution of the data into account, the highest OP levels were found in the unexplained infertility group. The reported levels of chlorinated compounds in cervical fluid were unexpectedly higher than those in FF (up to 20 times higher), despite the lower concentration of lipids in this fluid.

Ensslen et al 50 presented data for a series of 315 follicles from 45 patients. The concentrations of unspecified PCB congeners in FF ranged from 612 to 754 ng/g of lipid; those of HCH ranged from 209 to 302 and those of HCB ranged from 327 to 719 ng/g of lipid (no mean values available). These values did not differ significantly as a function of the presence or absence of oocytes in follicles or the fertilization status of the oocytes. No information was provided about patient age or sperm quality, but the author noted large differences in OP levels between FF specimens, even between specimens from the same patient.

Schmid et al 51 reported data for 59 infertile Swiss women who provided 66 samples: 59 from women with explained fertility and 7 from women with unexplained infertility. The analysis was complicated by 2 very high PCB determinations. The authors reported no differences in PCB concentrations between the groups with explained and unexplained fertility.

Several studies were initiated in Canada in response to increasing concern about the pollution of the Great Lakes. Jarrell et al 52 and a subsequent overview 54 screened 74 patients from 3 geographic areas: Halifax, Hamilton, and Vancouver. A strong association was found between geographic site and OP levels in S and FF fluids except for DDE. Outcome measures reflecting female fertility, such as fertilization rate and time to cleavage of the first egg, were not significantly associated with OP concentrations in serum and FF, except for HCB, the concentration of which was positively correlated with cleavage rate. This result was not considered biologically significant.

Series III corresponds to a study of 150 patients equally distributed between 6 Canadian cities (Calgary, Halifax, Hamilton, London, Toronto, and Vancouver). 53 –55 Three of the 21 patients included in the partial analysis 55,56 underwent unsuccessful fertilization procedures and 3 went on to become pregnant. Levels of a given OP were higher in serum than in FF and the concentrations in the 2 fluids were positively correlated. 56

Weiss et al 58 compared agricultural and industrial populations, by evaluating 31 Tanzanian and 21 German women for whom male infertility was the indication for IVF. Levels of PCB were significantly higher in the German population (Table 3), in which serum and FF concentrations of these compounds were strongly correlated. By contrast, Tanzanian women had higher levels of the pesticides, such as DDT, DDE, and dieldrin, and the serum and FF concentrations of these compounds were less strongly correlated in this population. A nonsignificant negative relationship between (DDT + DDE) concentration in serum and pregnancy rate was found in the German population, the only 1 of the 2 populations for which IVF outcomes were studied.

Series IV 62 studied 99 infertile Czech women with various infertility diagnoses, of various age groups and places of residence, whose partners had sperm of various levels of quality. Preliminary findings were published in earlier reports. 59 –61 In a logistic regression model, no statistically significant association was found between OP concentration in FF and the number or quality of oocytes retrieved, fertilization rate, embryo quality, or pregnancy rate. Nevertheless, nonsignificant negative relationships were reported between DDT concentration and diploid oocyte number between PCB 158 concentration and fertilization rate and between PCB 47 concentration and the number of frozen embryos and pregnancy rate.
Al-Saleh et al 63 screened a large cohort of 619 patients in Saudi Arabia. Multiple logistic regression analysis showed no adverse impact of DDT and DDE on IVF outcomes.

In series V, 64–66 multivariate-adjusted statistical models were used to determine prospectively the association between early pregnancy loss and serum levels of PCBs, HCB, DDT, and DDE. The study population was 765 women from the Boston area (United States) selected by a sampling strategy from 2350 couples undergoing IVF. Odds of failed implantation were significantly higher in women with higher concentrations of PCB-153, sum of PCB congeners and HCB.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The objective of this study was to review the evidence for an association between OP exposure and female fertility provided by studies evaluating IVF outcomes. Concentrations of OP were higher in follicular and cervical fluids than in serum. Rates of pregnancy following IVF were not significantly affected by exposure to OPs, but there was some evidence to suggest that OPs decreased oocyte or embryo quality and implantation.

Only a few of the OPs listed in the Stockholm Convention were determined in the selected studies, particular in the older ones. Exposure varied widely between geographic locations and also both within and between individuals. The field of analysis was also highly variable. Some studies screened for many OPs but detected only a few. 53,54 Some OPs, such as chlordecone, were not sought. Others, such as mirex, were considered to be absent from the environment in 1 study 49 but a major pollutant in another. 53,54 Most of the studies focused on PCB congeners for which contamination seemed to depend on the area of residence 52,58 and on DDT and its metabolites, which appeared to be more universal. Furthermore, there seemed to be a tendency toward a decrease in OP exposure over time (Table 3), as reported elsewhere. 64 This trend probably reflects a gradual decrease in pollutant use over the years 64 –68 and exposure levels must be taken into account to interpret and compare the study results. Nonetheless, this issue is complex, the trend is not uniform, and this study was not designed to tackle this question.

sec.title: Association With Fertility
sec.p: Studies of the amount of OP present per gram of lipid have indicated that most OPs accumulate to a greater degree in FF than in serum. 59,60,62 Human preovulatory FF contains little or no low-density lipoprotein , 35 whereas the concentration of high-density lipoprotein (HDL), the preferred carrier for several OPs, approaches that found in plasma. 69 Granulosa cells of the corpus luteum use LDL-cholesterol rather than HDL-cholesterol for progesterone production, but this LDL is available only after vascularization. 69 The toxicological consequences for fertility of this pattern of lipoprotein use by granulosa cells are unknown. However, taking PCBs as an example, the OP levels in FF (Table 3) appear to be within the range (10-10 000 ppb) known to induce experimental changes in mammalian oocyte maturation, fertilization, and embryo development. 70 Both DDT and DDE have also shown to affect the expression of ovarian growth factors in vivo and in vitro, possibly resulting in polycystic ovaries and impaired fertility. 71

The concentrations of OPs in cervical fluid were much greater than those in FF or seminal fluid. 49 Cervical transit is a fundamental step in spermatozoid protection, selection, and preparation for capacitation. 72 This unexpected result, which remains to be confirmed, supports the notion of a possible multipoint impact process, suggesting an action of OPs at many levels in the female genital tract, from spermatozoid transport to zygote implantation in the endometrium.

The OP exposure has been shown to be associated with precocious puberty, 73,74 menstrual cycle disruption, 74,75 spontaneous abortion, 76 reproductive organ cancer, 77 and infertility. 78 Occupational exposure to pesticides, but not specifically to OPs, has been strongly implicated in adverse reproductive outcomes, such as abortion, 79 low fecundity, and infertility. 80 For example, 2-bromopropane exposure results in primary ovarian failure, with histological damage to the follicles and vascularization similar to that caused by radiation or chemotherapy. 81 The Seveso accident in Italy in 1976 resulted in one of the highest known levels of population exposure to dioxin. No significant association was found between dioxin and female fertility, including endometriosis in particular, but a modification of the sex ratio at birth was observed. 82,83 The Yusho poisoning incident in Japan in 1968, in which rice bran oil was contaminated with PCBs and dioxin-related compounds, was reported to result in a trend toward high rates of spontaneous abortion, preterm delivery, and pregnancy loss, 84 although this trend was not supported by other studies. 85
–88 We identified only 3 studies (Table 4) exploring the question of the potential contribution of OPs to infertility. 49,51,61 Schmid found no difference in PCB concentration between the explained and unexplained infertility groups; however, 2 of the 59 patients had extremely high PCB levels and were excluded. The groups to which these patients belonged were not specified. In series II, OP concentrations were higher in the unexplained fertility group than in the explained infertility group (no statistical analysis), and lowest in the third group, the women who became pregnant after IVF. However, the type of infertility was not specified for the women who became pregnant. 49 In addition, the distinction between the 2 types of infertility was not clearly stated in either of the study. Jirsová et al 61 found that PCB concentrations were significantly higher in patients with endometriosis than in those with other IVF indications. In a more recent study from the same team, 62 a group of participants with unexplained infertility was identified, but no comparison was made with the explained infertility group. Given the poor quality score attributed to the first study and the absence of comparison in the second, it is not possible to draw any conclusions. Finally, Al-Saleh et al 63 reported an absence of effect of low concentrations of DDE.

sec.title: Association With Oocyte Quality, Fertilization, and Embryo Quality
sec.p: Female gametogenesis has been proposed as a critical target, for use in parallel with sperm-based assessments of male fertility, although it must be borne in mind that female gametogenesis begins in utero. 70,89 Series I, the studies by Jarrell et al and Younglai et al, and series IV 27,52,56,62 provided relevant information about OPs and oocyte or embryo quality (Table 4), but the evaluation criteria differed between these studies, making comparison and extrapolation difficult. However, although some indications of adverse effects of OPs were described, none of these studies reported a statistically significant adverse impact of OP exposure. The results are consistent with those of an in vitro animal study that showed no overt impact on oocytes or blastocysts, other than an effect on the apoptosis of oocyte cumulus cells, which was decreased by low OP concentration and increased by high OP concentration. 90

Fertilization was analyzed as an outcome in several of the selected studies 45,46,50,52,55,56,62,63 (Table 4). Most found no association or a nonsignificant association between OP exposure and fertilization. Only Younglai et al reported a significant correlation between fertilization rate and DDE levels in serum and in FF (Table 4). Fertilization in IVF depends on oocyte quality. Thus, these findings are consistent with reports of an absence of effect or of only nonsignificant effects of OP exposure on oocyte quality and fertilization.

sec.title: Association With Pregnancy Rate
sec.p: Pregnancy rate is a major end point indicative of success in IVF studies. 91 This outcome was evaluated in 2 studies 62,63 and no correlation with OP exposure was found. Al-saleh et al 63 hypothesized that their results might reflect low levels of OP. A negative correlation of borderline significance between PCB 47 concentrations and pregnancy rates was reported. 62 In series I, 45,46 II, 49 and the study by Younglai et al, 56 only the number of pregnant women was given (Table 4). In comparisons of women who became pregnant and those who did not, a trend toward higher levels of PCB, DDT, α-HCH, HCB, and dieldrin in those who did not become pregnant was observed. 45,46 Interestingly, although Younglai et al 56 found a negative association with DDE exposure (the pollutant most frequently detected in serum and FF), PCB 49 concentration was positively related to pregnancy rate. This finding is plausible in the context of a potential endocrine-disrupting effect of the chemical. 90

Pregnancy rates were not reported in a standard fashion: in the context of IVF, pregnancy may be defined as clinical or ongoing, 91 and only 2 studies distinguished between these 2 definitions. 62,63 In addition, pregnancy rates are highly dependent on embryo transfer policy 91 and can be calculated per started cycle, oocyte retrieval, or embryo transfer. No information about these indicators was provided by the selected studies, other than that by Al-Saleh et al. 63

Series V 65,66 was based on a sampling strategy focusing on early pregnancy loss (ie, failed implantation, chemical pregnancy, and spontaneous abortion). Failed implantation was significantly associated with the highest levels of PCB 153, sum of PCBs and HCB. As assessment was limited to these outcomes, no earlier evaluations of the IVF process, such as assessments of oocyte or embryo quality, which might account for implantation failure, were investigated.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: Human responses to toxicants vary as a function of genetic polymorphisms, sex, age- and development-related exposure, and preexisting disease. In addition, pollutants that act as endocrine disruptors may act as hormone receptor agonists or antagonists. 92 –94 It is becoming increasingly clear that OPs should be considered in terms of their “cocktail effect,” taking into account long-term exposure to low doses of multiple OPs acting synergistically. 95 None of the studies selected here applied such a complex global approach to OP exposure, using tools such as the toxic equivalency factor. 96

Our calculated lipid concentrations are consistent with published data for serum 33 and FF, 97 despite the underlying assumptions being based on methodologically weak and, in some cases, old publications. 34
–38 In addition, the transformed values were consistent, within an order of magnitude, with the wide range of levels reported by studies expressing results directly as a function of lipid content. 59
–62

We identified 2 geographic research clusters. European teams were the first to carry out research of this type in the 1980s. Studies in North America followed, with large studies by Canadians on pollution of the Great Lakes published in the 1990s and 2 recent studies carried out in the United States. No other evaluation of the impact of OPs on female fertility in the course of IVF treatment was identified from any other region (South America, Africa, or Asia). The number of relevant studies present in the multiple databases reviewed here was surprisingly small, given the ubiquitous nature of these environmental pollutants, the intensive use of pesticides, such as DDT, in tropical areas, the use of PCBs in industrial areas, and the link between contamination levels and place of residence. 98 In total, the studies retained for this review included just over 2000 women. Given the small sample sizes, the diversity of the populations recruited and variability in methodology, general averaging was not considered appropriate and was not carried out. The heterogeneous dispersion of pollutants worldwide, together with their cocktail effect, justifies further large multicenter studies.

Study quality was highly variable: some studies were strictly cross-sectional, whereas others were cohort or case-controlled studies (Table 2). Based on the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale, 31 older studies were considered to be of poorer quality. This scale gave greater weight to recent studies, despite the lower levels of exposure reported. In addition, heterogeneity in study protocols, objectives, and quality precluded data aggregation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The OPs accumulate not only in serum but also in follicular and cervical fluids. This accumulation had no significant effect on pregnancy following IVF in some studies. In other reports, there were indications of various degrees of significance, that is, oocyte, embryo quality, and implantation may have been impaired. Thus, IVF appears to be an appropriate context in which to address the role of OPs in unexplained infertility.

Oocyte and embryo quality assessment is important in studies carried out in the IVF context. Metabolomic profiling constitutes a new parameter in this assessment, independent of the usual grading by morphology, 99 and it may be useful for studies on environmental pollutants.

The correlation of FF exposure levels with serum concentrations 57,64 would facilitate sampling in the general population. Furthermore, the establishment of biobanks and analyses of a limited number of representative molecules appropriate for a particular place of residence would make it possible to carry out epidemiologic studies with sufficient power to assess the impact of various environmental pollutants.

The potentially adverse effect of pollutants on female fertility seems to have been little explored. The presence of pollutants in direct contact with oocytes and granulosa cells, in a way that could be considered cumulative, as found here, should drive further research and serve as a warning, encouraging the reduction in exposure to these pollutants in young women.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank E. Delvin and A. Djmeli for biochemical assistance; L. Jolin, M. Clar, and P. Dupont for bibliographic research support; M. P. Hitz and N. Lupien for translations; and D. Buch and L. Multigner for manuscript revision.
